title: Hotdog-Sandwich Taxonomy Consensus Framework

prerequisites: Secure participation from key stakeholder groups (Sandwich Purists, Hotdog Traditionalists, Culinary Professionals, Linguistic Scholars)
steps.outcome: Create legitimate, authoritative body to define food taxonomy standards
risks: Stakeholders refuse to participate or withdraw from process
Board unable to reach consensus on classification criteria

prerequisites: Conduct research on existing food classification frameworks
steps.outcome: Develop multi-level taxonomy that balances structural, cultural, and practical considerations
risks: Taxonomy seen as overly complex or confusing by general public
Disagreements on placement of specific food items

prerequisites: Engage with food service industry, regulators, and consumer groups
steps.outcome: Allow for both structural and cultural labels (e.g. 'Elongated Bread-Encased Meat Product' and 'Hotdog')
risks: Dual-labeling seen as overly burdensome or confusing
Disagreements on primary vs secondary labeling

prerequisites: Secure buy-in from major media outlets and food influencers
steps.outcome: Inform and engage general public on new food classification framework
risks: Persistent public resistance to new taxonomy

steps.outcome: Enshrine taxonomy system into law, regulations, and industry standards
risks: Failure to keep pace with evolving food landscape

resource_requirements: Funding for Taxonomy Review Board operations
Public relations/marketing budget for education campaign
